title: In a mixed-up market, growth is still a focus
text:
We’ll get another sense of sentiment on Wednesday when more than 700 investors and over 200 companies converge on Sydney for Citi’s annual Australian investment conference.

Growth a focus

John McLean, who heads Citi’s equity capital markets business in Australia, says the change in focus of what companies attendees want to meet is stark. Growth remains very much on the agenda.

“Five years ago it was very much a skew towards old industrial and perhaps the banks. This year we see much more of a focus on tech, fintech and Asia export stories.”

Australia’s boardrooms are sensing the market’s growth orientation and becoming more confident in their own prospects.

This shift also reflects the fact that Australia now has more globally relevant tech companies for investors to talk to, including Appen and Afterpay, both of whom Citi has raised capital for this year.

But what’s more interesting is that McLean’s sense that Australia’s boardrooms are sensing the market’s growth orientation and becoming more confident in their own prospects.

This is manifesting in some companies starting to make selected acquisitions offshore, or at least examine them more closely. But it’s also shown in the way some boards have rejected approaches from private equity, and shown a willingness to defend value.

Notably, McLean believes the growth orientation is starting to translate into firms reducing the hurdle rates they will target for deals – many, including the Reserve Bank, have argued that boards have held these too high for too long given just how low bond yields have fallen.

To be clear, McLean emphasises there is “an appropriate level of caution around making big investment decisions”. And, after the franking credits fight during the federal election, there is also a renewed sense of how highly investors value their dividends.

But even if it’s early days, the tilt towards growth is welcome news – for investment bankers of course, but also for an economy that could badly do with more in the way of animal spirits.
description: There's a fascinating juxtaposition between capital raisings by Latitude Financial and RFG. But in a fickle market, a Citi veteran says growth remains a focus.
